title: How to Make Eggnog French Toast

steps.headline: Whisk ingredients.
steps.description: Put the eggnog, pumpkin pie spice, and cinnamon in a medium bowl. Break the eggs into the same bowl. Whisk these ingredients together until well blended. Pour the mixture into a wide, shallow dish.

steps.headline: Prepare the pan.
steps.description: Take a nonstick skillet and coat it with butter or nonstick spray. Put it on the stove over medium heat. If you have an electric skillet, set the temperature to 300 degrees.

steps.headline: Dip the toast.
steps.description: Cut your French loaf into 12 even pieces. Each piece of bread should be about 1 to 1 ⁄2 inches (2.5 to 3.8 cm) thick. Take a piece of bread and dip it in the egg mixture. Move the piece of bread around to make sure the side is coated. Flip the piece of bread over, coating the other side in the same way. You can leave your bread in the mixture anywhere from 10 seconds to 1 minute. The longer you let it set, the more your bread will soak in the mixture. If you like bready French toast, don't let it soak too long. If you like moist French toast, let it soak longer. You can cut your pieces either thickness. The thicker the piece, the more bready your piece of French toast will be. Depending on how long your loaf is, you may have leftover bread.

steps.headline: Cook the toast.
steps.description: Take your coated bread and place it into your pan. Let it cook on this side until it is golden brown. Flip the bread over. Let it cook on this side until it is golden brown as well. Remove from the pan and place aside. Continue with each piece of bread until you have made them all. Top with syrup and butter or powdered sugar. This recipe makes 6 servings. If you want to keep your toast warm while you cook, cover the plate of toast with aluminum foil or place in a warmed oven.

steps.headline: Whisk wet ingredients.
steps.description: Take your eggs and break them into a large bowl. Add in eggnog, sugar, 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon, nutmeg, salt, and vanilla. Whisk together until well blended.

steps.headline: Coat the bread.
steps.description: Take the loaf of bread and, using a sharp knife, cut it into 1 inch (2.5 cm) cubes. Take the cubes and add them to the egg mixture. Toss the cubes in the mixture until they are completely coated.

steps.headline: Soak the bread.
steps.description: Grease a baking dish with butter or nonstick spray. Pour your ingredients in the dish. Make sure you add any extra mixture that did not coat the bread. Cover the dish with aluminum foil or plastic wrap. Place in the fridge overnight. Soaking the bread for this long allows the cubes to fully soak in the mixture, which makes the bread soft and creamy instead of bready. If you don't want to leave the dish overnight, you need to let it soak for at least 8 hours.

steps.headline: Prepare for baking.
steps.description: After you have let your dish soak, take it out of the fridge. Preheat your oven at 350 degrees. Mix the brown sugar and 1/2 teaspoon cinnamon in a bowl. Uncover the dish and sprinkle the mixture over the top of the dish.

steps.headline: Bake the toast.
steps.description: Bake the bread for 45 minutes uncovered. The egg mixture should be cooked and the bread should be golden brown. Serve in bowls and enjoy. This recipe makes 8 servings.

steps.headline: Prepare the pan.
steps.description: Coat a medium to large baking dish in butter or nonstick cooking spray. Cut your loaf of bread into slices. The slices should be 1 ⁄2 inches (3.8 cm) thick. Stack them in the pan in even, overlapping layers. You can use a rectangular dish or a deep dish pie pan.

steps.headline: Whisk your wet ingredients.
steps.description: Break the eggs into a large bowl. Pour the eggnog, vanilla, and cinnamon into the bowl. Whisk together the ingredients until they are completely blended.

steps.headline: Soak your bread.
steps.description: Pour your  mixture over the bread slices. Make sure you pour evenly so each slice is completely coated. Cover your dish with plastic wrap or aluminum foil. Place in the fridge overnight. If you don't want to let them set overnight, make sure you leave it in the fridge for at least 3 hours.

steps.headline: Preheat your oven.
steps.description: Take your pan out of the fridge. Preheat your over at 350 degrees. Uncover your pan and set it aside.

steps.headline: Make your topping.
steps.description: Put the butter, syrup, and brown sugar in a saucepan. Stir them together and cook over medium heat. Keep stirring the mixture until it begins to foam and bubble.

steps.headline: Bake your bread.
steps.description: Slowly pour your topping over the bread slices. Make sure you coat them and pour some in between the slices. Bake uncovered for 40 to 45 minutes. The top of the bread should be golden brown. Dust with powdered sugar and serve. This recipe makes 8 servings.

text: Making Eggnog French Toast Whisk ingredients. Put the eggnog, pumpkin pie spice, and cinnamon in a medium bowl. Break the eggs into the same bowl. Whisk these ingredients together until well blended. Pour the mixture into a wide, shallow dish. Prepare the pan. Take a nonstick skillet and coat it with butter or nonstick spray. Put it on the stove over medium heat. If you have an electric skillet, set the temperature to 300 degrees. Dip the toast. Cut your French loaf into 12 even pieces. Each piece of bread should be about 1 to 1 ⁄2 inches (2.5 to 3.8 cm) thick. Take a piece of bread and dip it in the egg mixture. Move the piece of bread around to make sure the side is coated. Flip the piece of bread over, coating the other side in the same way. You can leave your bread in the mixture anywhere from 10 seconds to 1 minute. The longer you let it set, the more your bread will soak in the mixture. If you like bready French toast, don't let it soak too long. If you like moist French toast, let it soak longer. You can cut your pieces either thickness. The thicker the piece, the more bready your piece of French toast will be. Depending on how long your loaf is, you may have leftover bread. Cook the toast. Take your coated bread and place it into your pan. Let it cook on this side until it is golden brown. Flip the bread over. Let it cook on this side until it is golden brown as well. Remove from the pan and place aside. Continue with each piece of bread until you have made them all. Top with syrup and butter or powdered sugar. This recipe makes 6 servings. If you want to keep your toast warm while you cook, cover the plate of toast with aluminum foil or place in a warmed oven. Cooking Baked Eggnog French Toast Whisk wet ingredients. Take your eggs and break them into a large bowl. Add in eggnog, sugar, 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon, nutmeg, salt, and vanilla. Whisk together until well blended. Coat the bread. Take the loaf of bread and, using a sharp knife, cut it into 1 inch (2.5 cm) cubes. Take the cubes and add them to the egg mixture. Toss the cubes in the mixture until they are completely coated. Soak the bread. Grease a baking dish with butter or nonstick spray. Pour your ingredients in the dish. Make sure you add any extra mixture that did not coat the bread. Cover the dish with aluminum foil or plastic wrap. Place in the fridge overnight. Soaking the bread for this long allows the cubes to fully soak in the mixture, which makes the bread soft and creamy instead of bready. If you don't want to leave the dish overnight, you need to let it soak for at least 8 hours. Prepare for baking. After you have let your dish soak, take it out of the fridge. Preheat your oven at 350 degrees. Mix the brown sugar and 1/2 teaspoon cinnamon in a bowl. Uncover the dish and sprinkle the mixture over the top of the dish. Bake the toast. Bake the bread for 45 minutes uncovered. The egg mixture should be cooked and the bread should be golden brown. Serve in bowls and enjoy. This recipe makes 8 servings. Making Eggnog French Toast Casserole Prepare the pan. Coat a medium to large baking dish in butter or nonstick cooking spray. Cut your loaf of bread into slices. The slices should be 1 ⁄2 inches (3.8 cm) thick. Stack them in the pan in even, overlapping layers. You can use a rectangular dish or a deep dish pie pan. Whisk your wet ingredients. Break the eggs into a large bowl. Pour the eggnog, vanilla, and cinnamon into the bowl. Whisk together the ingredients until they are completely blended. Soak your bread. Pour your  mixture over the bread slices. Make sure you pour evenly so each slice is completely coated. Cover your dish with plastic wrap or aluminum foil. Place in the fridge overnight. If you don't want to let them set overnight, make sure you leave it in the fridge for at least 3 hours. Preheat your oven. Take your pan out of the fridge. Preheat your over at 350 degrees. Uncover your pan and set it aside. Make your topping. Put the butter, syrup, and brown sugar in a saucepan. Stir them together and cook over medium heat. Keep stirring the mixture until it begins to foam and bubble. Bake your bread. Slowly pour your topping over the bread slices. Make sure you coat them and pour some in between the slices. Bake uncovered for 40 to 45 minutes. The top of the bread should be golden brown. Dust with powdered sugar and serve. This recipe makes 8 servings.
